snippet: The discovery that the National Security Agency routinely collects information on American citizens has left the Obama administration struggling to explain previous statements that seem, at best, misleading.
abstract: Discovery that National Security Agency routinely collects information on American citizens has left Obama administration struggling to explain previous statements that now seem, at best, misleading; intelligence officials have long tried to debunk what they called popular myth about agency that its surveillance efforts gathered information on millions of Americans, not exclusively focusing on terrorists or other foreign targets.

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: The discovery that the National Security Agency routinely collects information on American citizens has left the Obama administration struggling to explain previous statements that seem, at best, misleading.

headline.seo: Earlier Denials Put Intelligence Chief in Awkward Position
headline.main: Earlier Denials Put Intelligence Chief in Awkward Position
headline.print_headline: Disclosures on N.S.A. Surveillance Put Awkward Light on Previous Denials
